title: Campaign Finance Board fines Advance Group
text:
Jefferson Siegel/New York Daily News During the 2013 campaign, the Advance Goup helped NYCLASS spent millions to aggressively back candidates who supported ending horse carriages in Central Park and attacked those who fought their cause. A political consultant illegally helped a well-funded anti-horse carriage group avoid contribution limits in supporting City Council candidates in 2013, the Campaign Finance Board voted Thursday.
The Advance Group choreographed support for Council candidates Laurie Cumbo and Mark Levine in concert with New Yorkers for Clean, Livable & Safe Streets (NYCLASS), the board ruled.
During the 2013 campaign, NYCLASS spent millions to aggressively back candidates who supported ending horse carriages in Central Park and attacked those who fought their cause.
The CFB found that by working for NYCLASS and Cumbo and Levine’s campaigns at the same time, Advance helped NYCLASS dodge rules limiting how much they can steer to specific candidates.

(Angus Mordant for New York Daily News) Enlarge The Advance Group choreographed support for Council candidates Laurie Cumbo, left, and Mark Levine in concert with New Yorkers for Clean, Livable & Safe Streets, the board ruled.
NYCLASS is considered an “independent spender,” and isn’t supposed to coordinate its spending with specific candidates.
The illegal coordination between an independent spender and a political consultant was investigated by the CFB and state Attorney General Eric Schneiderman.
At a board meeting Thursday, the board voted to hit Advance with a $15,000 fine, with another $10,800 owed to the state. In December the board hit NYCLASS with a $26,000 fine.
At a board meeting Thursday, the board voted to hit Advance with a $15,000 fine, with another $10,800 owed to the state. In December the board hit NYCLASS with a $26,000 fine. “These violations strike at the very heart of our campaign finance program,” said CFB member Mark Piazza. “When a consultant’s actions make it impossible for their clients to comply with the law, the Board will hold the consultant accountable.”
NYCLASS’ work with Advance Group during the 2013 campaign was also investigated by the FBI, which looked at whether then-candidate Bill de Blasio’s uncle steered donations through NYCLASS to secretly fund attacks on de Blasio’s chief rival, former Council Speaker Christine Quinn.
At one point the Advance Group’s founder, Scott Levenson, twice approached Quinn’s aides to say if she didn’t back the horse carriage ban, NYCLASS would spend money to attack her.
Quinn didn’t back down and lost the race.
